title: How to Recognize and Treat a Ruptured Cyst on a Dog

steps.title: Dogs can develop different kinds of cysts.
steps.content: Dogs can develop different kinds of cysts. True cysts develop near glands and often form on a pup’s eyelids. Follicular, or epidermoid cysts, form in your dog’s hair follicles. Sebaceous cysts are also found around your pet’s hair follicles, and especially likely to get infected. Other dogs may have false cysts, which usually form after some type of injury. [2] X Trustworthy Source American Kennel Club The American Kennel Club (AKC) is a purebred dog pedigree registry in the United States. The AKC advocates for the responsible ownership of dogs and promotes purebred dog events, such as the Westminster Dog Show. Go to source Most cysts have a “secretory lining,” or a special lining that surrounds the entire cyst. False cysts don’t have this type of lining, and they only appear in dead tissue. Dermoid cysts are a rare type of cysts that a few pups develop before they’re born—chances are, this isn’t the kind of cyst your dog is dealing with.

steps.title: Sebaceous cysts are the type that commonly burst.
steps.content: Sebaceous cysts are the type that commonly burst. When they get big enough, the cyst may burst due to its own pressure. These cysts are generally harmless, but they can get infected if not cared for properly. [3] X Research source

steps.title: Sebaceous cysts form when hair follicles get blocked.
steps.content: Sebaceous cysts form when hair follicles get blocked. Your pup naturally secretes sebum from their oil (sebaceous) glands, which spreads onto their hair and skin. [4] X Research source When the hair follicle gets covered with debris and dirt, this new sebum has nowhere to go, and ends up forming a cyst. Over time, these cysts can grow bigger and bigger as they fill up with extra secretions. [5] X Research source

steps.title: Injury, pressure points, and sun damage can also lead to cysts.
steps.content: Injury, pressure points, and sun damage can also lead to cysts. Follicular cysts usually form after some type of damage to the hair follicle, or when a pore gets blocked. In a similar fashion, true cysts appear when the sweat gland gets blocked off. False cysts, on the other hand, tend to pop up when your dog has a bad reaction to a shot. [6] X Trustworthy Source American Kennel Club The American Kennel Club (AKC) is a purebred dog pedigree registry in the United States. The AKC advocates for the responsible ownership of dogs and promotes purebred dog events, such as the Westminster Dog Show. Go to source Other causes could be abscesses, tumors, or allergies. Talk to a vet to determine the underlying cause.

steps.title: Follicular cysts appear on or beneath your pet’s skin.
steps.content: Follicular cysts appear on or beneath your pet’s skin. These cysts are round and have a bluish tint. You’ll probably find this type of cyst on your dog’s head, trunk, or neck, where you’ll see a gray or yellow, cheese-like substance leaking out. Unfortunately, this cyst tends to smell bad once it gets infected. [7] X Research source

steps.title: True cysts pop up near your pet’s eyes or ears.
steps.content: True cysts pop up near your pet’s eyes or ears. They usually form a lump- or sac-like shape, and they typically look blue or dark. These cysts are filled with a yellow fluid. [8] X Research source

steps.title: Sebaceous cysts develop along the top of the skin.
steps.content: Sebaceous cysts develop along the top of the skin. These cysts appear white or blue. When they rupture, you’ll notice a brown or gray-white discharge that looks similar to cottage cheese. [9] X Research source You’ll probably find these cysts on your dog’s neck, torso, upper legs, or head.

steps.title: False cysts develop after an injury.
steps.content: False cysts develop after an injury. These cysts are dark in color and are actually filled with blood. [10] X Research source

steps.title: Clean and bandage the ruptured cyst temporarily.
steps.content: Clean and bandage the ruptured cyst temporarily. Sometimes, a cyst can open, or “ulcerate,” without actually bursting. If this happens, clean out the cyst and carefully wrap it up with a clean bandage. Don’t try to pop or remove the cyst yourself, though. [11] X Research source You can clean the area with warm tap water or a warm saline mixture made with 1 tsp (5.9 g) of salt and 2 c (470 mL) of distilled water. Don’t use any shampoo, soap, alcohol, hydrogen peroxide, or other substance to clean the area, unless your vet specifically suggests it. [12] X Research source

steps.title: Take your dog to the vet as soon as you can after the cyst ruptures.
steps.content: Take your dog to the vet as soon as you can after the cyst ruptures. There, veterinary professionals may remove the cyst with a laser. Vets won’t usually squeeze or drain a ruptured cyst since that won’t get rid of the blockage completely and could cause the cyst to reform. [13] X Research source After the surgery, keep your pet in a quiet, closed-off area. Follow your vet’s after-care instructions; you may need to give your pup some special medication, or change their bandages regularly.

steps.title: Remove cysts from your dog’s toes through surgery, a CO₂ laser, or therapy.
steps.content: Remove cysts from your dog’s toes through surgery, a CO₂ laser, or therapy. During surgery, a vet will physically remove the cysts and stitch your dog’s toes together while the area heals. With a CO₂ laser, your vet will vaporize the cysts without hurting the rest of the paw. For a more long-term treatment plan, vets might treat the cysts with steroids and antibiotics. [14] X Research source Antibiotic regimens can last for at least 6 weeks.

steps.title: Fortunately, cysts go away with treatment.
steps.content: Fortunately, cysts go away with treatment. After a vet-recommended treatment, your dog should be able to fully recover. [15] X Research source Always follow your vet’s recommended aftercare, so your dog doesn’t come down with an infection.

steps.title: Certain dog breeds are more likely to develop cysts.
steps.content: Certain dog breeds are more likely to develop cysts. Boxers, Shih Tzus, Basset Hounds, and Schnauzers are genetically more likely to develop follicular cysts. Hairless breeds, like the Chinese Crested Dog and Mexican Hairless Dog, may also develop follicular cysts since their hair follicles are so inactive. [16] X Trustworthy Source American Kennel Club The American Kennel Club (AKC) is a purebred dog pedigree registry in the United States. The AKC advocates for the responsible ownership of dogs and promotes purebred dog events, such as the Westminster Dog Show. Go to source Rhodesian Ridgebacks and Kerry Blue Terriers are more genetically likely to get dermoid cysts. Labradors, Cocker Spaniels, Poodles, and Schnauzers are also prone to cysts.
